concept.title: Image alignment, placement, and sizing
concept.shortdesc: The align, placement, width, and height attributes of the image element are used to specify the placement and size of images when generated to an output delivery format.

conbody.p: The placement of the image on the output page or screen is defined in the placement and align attributes. The placement attribute can be set to inline (placing the image inline with the text in the paragraph in which it is placed) or break (placing the image in its own block, with space above and below it). The align attribute has valid values of left, right, center and current. These values specify how the image will be aligned on the page or screen. The align attribute only has an effect if the placement is set to break.
To display the image in its own block, use the image element independently of a paragraph element, set the placement attribute to break, and the alignment to left, right, or center.

To display an image within a paragraph or other block element, set the placement attribute to inline, and either omit the align attribute or set it to current (to inherit the alignment settings of the element in which the image is contained).

The image element includes height and width attributes. These attributes are used to store the intended display height and width of the image in the output, expressed in one of a variety of units, including pixels (px), centimetres (cm), points (pt) and inches (in).
conbody.note: If you are using the DITA Open Toolkit for publishing, you will get the best results if you always use pixels as the unit for height and width attributes, with the dimensions being the actual dimensions of the image. (In other words, do not scale the image using the height and width attributes.)

lq.reftitle: Craig Sandvik, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

p.lq: Up until DITA-OT 1.5, the fo plugin scales graphics from the dimensions supplied in the DITA source to 72 dots per inch. This enlarges most graphics since typical modern screenshots are at 96 dpi. Some workarounds for earlier versions: - If your authoring tool allows it, remove the height and width attributes from the <image> element in DITA source. - For the <image> element in DITA source, set the height and width attributes with px (pixel) units, as in "100px" - If you use a customization XSL, override named template "placeImage". Copy and paste the template from xsl/fo/commons.xsl, then comment out the code that scales @height and @width, or change 72 to a larger number (128 works well for print).

lq.p: Bitmap (or "raster") images are collections of pixels. Their dimensions are normally expressed in pixels. When displayed on a computer monitor, which is itself made up of pixels, what you see on the screen is what you expect to see. A pixel is a variable measurement unit... it has a different physical size depending upon the type of monitor or display being used.

However, when you output a bitmap image to paper (or a paper simulator like PDF), the pixels need to be somehow converted to fixed physical measurements, such as millimetres. Some programs will scale the images to a fixed size using the resolution of the printing device. For example, if you have a 300 pixels per inch (DPI) printer, and you print a 300 pixel wide picture, its physical size on the printout will be 1 inch.

When using the PDF2 transformation in the DITA Open Toolkit, the process uses 72 DPI as the basis for conversion to a fixed size. (72 DPI was the typical resolution for a cathode ray tube computer monitor at an 800 x 600 setting.) Thus, our 300 pixel image will be displayed at a physical size of 300/72 inches, or 4.2 inches.
So, this is why your images seem to be displaying at a larger size in PDF than it in HTML format. Your monitor is displaying the image at perhaps 96 DPI, while the PDF is showing it at 72 DPI.

Now, for the possible solution. Firstly, make sure you always set the width and height attributes for the image to the dimensions of the image, in pixels. Don't use other measurements, such as 5cm. Don't scale the image by using a measurement other than the natural size of the image. Always include the px unit. (height="500" is very different to height="500px")
